5) Beginning with the 55th year, the number of deaths per year will increase to 5 (3% of 168 = 5.04), while the births will still be 6.  The population will increase at the rate of 1 per year, reaching 175 at the end of the 61st year.
6) Beginning with the 62nd year, the number of births per year will increase to 7 (4% of 175 = 7), while the deaths will still be 5.  The population will increase at the rate of 2 per year, reaching 201 at the end of the 75th year.
7) Beginning with the 76th year, the number of births per year will increase to 8 (4% of 201 = 8.04) and the number of deaths will increase to 6 (3% of 201 = 6.03).  The population will continue to increase at the rate of 2 per year.  The population will never again increase by only 1 per year.
Although the 26th year is the first year that the population increases by more than 1, the 25th year is not the last year that it increases by 1.  The last year that the population increases by 1 is the 61st year, when the population reaches 175.
Response:
Let P​n ​be the number of people alive at the beginning of the n-th year (P​1  = 100).  
During that year  

 births  = ⌊0.04 P​n ⌋, deaths  = ⌊0.03 P​n ⌋,  

so the change in population is  

 Δ(P​n ) = ⌊0.04 P​n ⌋ − ⌊0.03 P​n ⌋.  

We must discover (i) for which integer populations P the value Δ(P) equals 1, and
(ii) in what year such a population is last encountered.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
1.  When is Δ(P) = 1 ?

Write P = 25m + r with 0 ≤ r ≤ 24 (m = ⌊P/25⌋).

Then  
 ⌊0.04 P⌋ = ⌊(25m+r)/25⌋ = m,  
 ⌊0.03 P⌋ = ⌊(75m+3r)/100⌋.

Hence Δ(P)=1 iff

 m − ⌊(75m+3r)/100⌋ = 1
 ⇔ m–1 ≤ (75m+3r)/100 < m
 ⇔ 25m−100 ≤ 3r < 25m.                (★)

Because 0 ≤ 3r ≤ 72, (★) can hold only while 25m−100 ≤ 72, i.e. m ≤ 6.
Examining m = 4,5,6 we obtain the r that satisfy (★):

 m = 4 ⇒ 25·4−100 = 0   0 ≤ 3r < 100  (all r = 0…24)
   P  = 100 … 124

 m = 5 ⇒ 25·5−100 = 25  25 ≤ 3r < 125  (r = 9…24)
   P  = 134 … 149

 m = 6 ⇒ 25·6−100 = 50  50 ≤ 3r < 150  (r = 17…24)
   P  = 167 … 174

For m ≥ 7 no r satisfies (★).  
Thus

 Δ(P) = 1 precisely for
 P ∈ {100–124, 134–149, 167–174},

and for every P ≥ 175 we have Δ(P) ≥ 2.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
2.  Follow the population year by year

Starting with P₁ = 100:

• Years 1–25 (P = 100→124): Δ = 1 each year  
 After 25 years P = 125.

• P = 125–133: Δ = 2 (check one value: for P = 125,  ⌊0.04·125⌋=5, ⌊0.03·125⌋=3)  
 125 → 127 → 129 → 131 → 133 → 135.  
 This takes 5 years (years 26–30).

• Years 31–45 (P = 135→149): Δ = 1 each year (15 years).  
 After year 45 P = 150.

• P = 150–166: Δ = 2 each year.  
 150 → 152 → 154 → 156 → 158 → 160 → 162 → 164 → 166 → 168.  
 That is 9 years (years 46–54).

• Years 55–61 (P = 168→174): Δ = 1 each year (7 years).  
 At the end of year 61 P = 175.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
3.  What happens after P = 174 ?

Because 174 is the largest population for which Δ = 1, every year that starts with
P ≥ 175 has Δ ≥ 2.  Indeed, for P = 175 we have

 ⌊0.04·175⌋ = 7, ⌊0.03·175⌋ = 5, Δ = 2.

Hence year 61 (which began with 174 people) is the very last year in which the colony grows by exactly one person.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
Final answer: 61

Question:
If 125207 is "Hi", and 031993121212 is "Dude", then 125207031993121212 is "Hi Dude".
Then what is 799717777010909230151693122001983?
Hint: Look at the length of the strings with relation to the text output
Human Solution:
It's "You Are Great".
Separate the numbers into groups of three, and then add up the three numbers. The total amount will point to a certain letter, and if you continue doing it until all numbers are used, it'll form the sentence "You Are Great".
Response:
Observe that every letter is represented by a block of three digits.  
For the examples given:

125207  → 125 | 207  
       1 + 2 + 5 = 8 → 8th letter = H  
       2 + 0 + 7 = 9 → 9th letter = i  
Thus 125207 = “Hi”.

031993121212 → 031 | 993 | 121 | 212  
       0 + 3 + 1 = 4 → D  
       9 + 9 + 3 = 21 → u  
       1 + 2 + 1 = 4 → d  
       2 + 1 + 2 = 5 → e  
Hence 031993121212 = “Dude”.

The rule is therefore:  
Each 3-digit block encodes a letter whose position in the alphabet equals the sum of the three digits (A = 1, B = 2, …, Z = 26).

Decode 799717777010909230151693122001983 by splitting it into 3-digit blocks and summing:

799 → 7+9+9 = 25 → Y  
717 → 7+1+7 = 15 → O  
777 → 7+7+7 = 21 → U  
010 → 0+1+0 = 1  → A  
909 → 9+0+9 = 18 → R  
230 → 2+3+0 = 5  → E  
151 → 1+5+1 = 7  → G  
693 → 6+9+3 = 18 → R  
122 → 1+2+2 = 5  → E  
001 → 0+0+1 = 1  → A  
983 → 9+8+3 = 20 → T  

Reading the letters in order gives:

Y  O  U   A  R  E   G  R  E  A  T  
→ “You are great”

Final answer: You are great

Question:
Two aging mathematics professors, Al Gebra and Cal Culus were sitting at their favourite Thai restaurant, Phun Kshuns, reminiscing about when they first met, while their waiter, Theo Rumsanrools (who also took Professor Gebra's Advanced Mathematics course at Cart Eshian University) eavesdropped on their conversation as he brought them their meals.
"You know what occurred to me the other day, Cal?" asked Professor Gebra.
"What's that?" said Professor Culus.
"Well, when we met, the square of your age contained the same three digits as the square of my age, just in a different order," Professor Gebra continued.
"This will really blow your socks off then, Al! If you take the square of the sum of our ages when we met and split it into two 2-digit numbers, you'd have my age then and your age now!" Professor Culus exclaimed.
Wanting to impress his professor, Theo interjected.
"I thought you were much younger than that, Professor Gebra," Theo said.
Said Professor Gebra, "And just how old am I then, young fellow?"
Hint: Find all pairs of numbers whose squares share the same digits and compare the numbers to the two digit strings formed by the square of their sum
Human Solution:
"Well, you're 81, sir," Theo replied.
"Right you are! And how did you figure that out so quickly?" Professor Gebra asked.
"You said the square of your ages when you and Professor Culus met had only three digits, so the oldest you could have been was 31. That means that there were only a few possible ages the two of you could have been. Those being (with the associated squares):
14 & 31 (196 & 961),
13 & 31 (169 & 961),
16 & 25 (256 & 625),
12 & 21 (144 & 441),
13 & 14 (169 & 196).
Now the square of the sum of each of these pair of ages are respectively:
2025,
1936,
1681,
1089,
729.
And from those figures I concluded that Professor Culus must have been 16 when you met and hence you, Professor Gebra, are now 81!" Theo explained.
"Aren't you a bright young fellow! You should come and study my Advanced Mathematics course at Cart Eshian University!" Professor Gebra exclaimed.
"Uh, I already do," Theo said sheepishly.
Response:
Let  

a = Al’s age when the two professors first met,  
c = Cal’s age when they first met,  

so that at the present moment  

A = Al’s current age,  
C = Cal’s current age,  
t = years since they met = A – a = C – c.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
1.  The “same three digits” condition
--------------------------------------------------------------------
At the time they met the squares of their ages had the same three
digits in a different order.  
Hence a² and c² are both three–digit numbers containing the same
digits.  
Thus 10 ≤ a, c ≤ 31 (because 10² = 100 and 31² = 961).

List of three–digit perfect squares in this range, together with the
multisets of their digits:

10² = 100  → {0,0,1}  
11² = 121  → {1,1,2}  
12² = 144  → {1,4,4}  
13² = 169  → {1,6,9}  
14² = 196  → {1,6,9}  
15² = 225  → {2,2,5}  
16² = 256  → {2,5,6}  
17² = 289  → {2,8,9}  
18² = 324  → {2,3,4}  
19² = 361  → {1,3,6}  
20² = 400  → {0,0,4}  
21² = 441  → {1,4,4}  
22² = 484  → {4,4,8}  
23² = 529  → {2,5,9}  
24² = 576  → {5,6,7}  
25² = 625  → {2,5,6}  
26² = 676  → {6,6,7}  
27² = 729  → {2,7,9}  
28² = 784  → {4,7,8}  
29² = 841  → {1,4,8}  
30² = 900  → {0,0,9}  
31² = 961  → {1,6,9}

From the list, the only distinct squares sharing the same three digits
are

12² = 144 and 21² = 441,  
13² = 169, 14² = 196, 31² = 961,  
16² = 256 and 25² = 625.

Therefore the possible (a, c) pairs are

(12, 21), (21, 12), (13, 14), (14, 13), (13, 31), (31, 13),
(14, 31), (31, 14), (16, 25), (25, 16).

--------------------------------------------------------------------
2.  The “square-of-the-sum” condition
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Cal says: “If you take the square of the sum of our ages when we met
and split it into two two-digit numbers, you’d have my age then and
your age now.”

Hence (a + c)² is a four-digit number whose first two digits are c and
whose last two digits are A.  Symbolically,

(a + c)² = 100·c + A,          (1)

with 10 ≤ c ≤ 31 and 10 ≤ A ≤ 99.

Test each candidate pair:

1. (12, 21): (12 + 21)² = 33² = 1089  → 10|89 (first two digits 10 ≠ 21)  
2. (21, 12): (21 + 12)² = 33² = 1089  → 10|89 (10 ≠ 12)  
3. (13, 14): (13 + 14)² = 27² = 729   (three-digit, impossible)  
4. (14, 13): same failure  
5. (13, 31): (44)² = 1936 → 19|36 (19 ≠ 31)  
6. (31, 13): same failure  
7. (14, 31): (45)² = 2025 → 20|25 (20 ≠ 31)  
8. (31, 14): same failure  
9. (16, 25): (41)² = 1681 → 16|81 (first two digits 16 = c)  ✓  
10.(25, 16): (41)² = 1681 → 16|81 (16 ≠ 25)  ✗

The only pair satisfying (1) is

a = 25, c = 16,  (a + c)² = 1681 = 100·16 + 81.

Thus Cal’s age at their first meeting was 16 and Al’s present age is 81.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
3.  Consistency check
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Time elapsed: t = A – a = 81 – 25 = 56 years.  
Cal’s present age: C = c + t = 16 + 56 = 72.

Everything is plausible: two elderly professors, aged 81 and 72,
reminiscing about meeting 56 years ago when they were 25 and 16, and
the numerical conditions are exactly met.

Therefore Professor Al Gebra’s present age is 81.

Final answer: 81

Question:
Kurt & Rod were hanging around the window at school munching the last of their Rnkfurers hoard.  They spotted their neighbor lounging in the enclosed courtyard, looking hungry.
"Patty O'Furniture!  Good to see you!  Want a Rnkfurter?"
"A what?"
Kurt handed her the last he had.  She bit in, and her face lit up like a newly-coined metaphor.
"Where can I get more of these?"
"Rod and I were about to go order some more.  But there's a catch: we always order so one of us gets the quantity that the other has for a percentage."  Patty's blank look bade him explain.  "In our first batch, we got a total of 25 -- 20 for me, and 5 for Rod.  I had 20, and he had 20% of the total."
"And you think you can do that for three people?  You get my percentage, and I get Rod's?  I don't think we can do it."
Rod had been thinking about it, and rattled off three numbers to her.
"Those aren't right.  The last one isn't the right percentage; there's an added fraction."
"So?  My mom says they're the same on her old phonograph speeds."
Patty looked at Kurt, each waiting for the other to give an opinion.  Finally, she gestured at the empty wrapper in his hand.
"I'll round off a little for a week's supply of these.  Let's go!"
Since Rnkfurters come in cases of 25, 50, and 100, they had to leave 10 with the storekeeper to make the numbers work, but they got their munchies.
How many did each student get this time?
Hint: The old phonograph speeds were typically 16, 33-1/3, 45, and 78 RPM.
Human Solution:
27 for Kurt, 30 for Patty, and 33 for Rod.
That's 30% for Kurt and 33-1/3% for Patty.
Method:
Let K, P, and R stand for the quantity each of them had.  Let T be the total, K+P+R.
Now, since Kurt's percentage equals Patty's quantity, we get
100*K/T = P.
Similarly,
100*P/T = R plus a fraction.  Now, look at the common factor, 100/T.  Let's call this F, the factor relating one quantity to the next.
K*F = P and P*F = R (plus a fraction),
and K*F^2 = R (plus a fraction).
The clue about the phonograph leaves us looking for a triple with 33 Rnkfurters for Rod, with Patty getting 33-1/3% (one-third) of the total.
P = T/3
P = (K+P+33)/3 -- remember, R=33
Now, combine this with 100*K/T = P, and a bit of algebra gives us the required answer.
-------------
Alternately, there are 11 triples that fit the factor requirement (courtesy of a short computer program), ranging from (19, 25, 32) to (2376, 96, 3).  The ones that total 10 less than a multiple of 25 are
27, 30, 33
63, 45, 32
891, 90, 9
Given the phonograph clue, I expect you can recognize that the first triple above is the answer.
Response:
Let  

 K = number Kurt gets  
 R = number Rod gets  
 P = number Patty gets  
 T = K + R + P = total they really want to take home  

The boys’ “percentage game” now has to work for three people.

1.  Patty is to receive exactly the number that equals Rod’s percentage of the total  
   P = (R∕T)·100 .   (†)

2.  Kurt is to receive the number that equals Patty’s percentage of the total.  
     Patty’s percentage is generally not an integer (e.g. 33⅓ %), but Patty agrees to
     “round off a little”; i.e. Kurt will take the nearest whole number to that
     percentage:  
   K = round ( (P∕T)·100 ).   (‡)

3.  The shop packs Rnkfurters only in lots of 25, 50 or 100.  
    They finally buy the next larger multiple of 25 and leave 10 with the
    store-keeper, so
   T ≡ –10 (mod 25) ⟺ T ≡ 15 (mod 25).   (§)

──────────────────────────
Working with the exact condition (†)

From (†) P = 100R/T  ⇒ T divides 100R.  
Choose the smallest total that also satisfies (§).  
The least positive integer ≡ 15 (mod 25) is 90, and 90 | 100R as soon as R is a
multiple of 9.

Write R = 9n.  
Then P = 100·9n / 90 = 10n.

──────────────────────────
Now impose the “rounded” condition (‡)

Patty’s percentage is

  (P∕T)·100 = (10n/90)·100 = (100/9)n = 11 1⁄9 n .

The nearest integer to 11 1⁄9 n is 11 n, so

  K = 11n.

Thus

  K : P : R = 11n : 10n : 9n
  T = 30n.

But we already fixed T = 90, so 30n = 90 ⇒ n = 3.

Therefore

  K = 11·3 = 33,  P = 10·3 = 30,  R = 9·3 = 27,
  T = 33 + 30 + 27 = 90.

──────────────────────────
Checking the conditions

•  Rod’s percentage of 90 is 27⁄90·100 = 30 %.  
   Patty indeed gets 30 Rnkfurters. ✓

•  Patty’s percentage of 90 is 30⁄90·100 = 33⅓ %.  
   Rounded to the nearest whole number this is 33, which is what Kurt gets. ✓  
   (Patty’s quibble about “the added fraction” is the extra ⅓ %, i.e. the
   phonograph-speed “33 1⁄3”.)

•  Total wanted is 90; the boys can only buy in case lots.  
   The next multiple of 25 is 100, so they buy 100 and leave 10 behind. ✓

Hence the only possible distribution that fits every remark in the story is

 Kurt 33   Patty 30   Rod 27.

Final answer: Kurt gets 33, Patty gets 30, and Rod gets 27 Rnkfurters.

Question:
A man is standing on a rock in the middle of a circular lake of radius 1. There is a tiger on the shore of the lake that can run four times as fast you can swim, however the tiger cannot swim. The tiger is hungry and always attempts to keep the distance between the two of you at a minimum. How can you safely swim to shore?
Assume that as long as you can get to the shore before the tiger gets to you (even if it is only a split-second before), you will be safe.
Hint: Use the factor of 4 to your advantage
Human Solution:
Until you are more than 1/4 of the radius away from the rock you can swim fast enough so that you can keep the tiger the furthest distance possible from you. Regardless of which direction the tiger moves around the circle, you swim the other way, always keeping the rock between you and the tiger.  While you are doing this you will be able to move outward, since you will have some energy to spare.
Before long you will be 1/4 of the radius away from the center and the tiger will be 180 degrees away. At this point swim straight to the point on the shore furthest from the tiger. You will be able to get there in 3/4 units of time, while it will take the tiger pi/4 =~ 0.7854 units of time.
Response:
Let your swimming speed be v = 1 and the tiger’s running speed 4v = 4.  
The lake is a circle of radius 1 with centre O.  You start at O, the tiger is somewhere on the circumference.

1.  Choose a radius  
        r such that 1 – π⁄4 < r < ¼.  
    Numerically, 1 – π⁄4 ≈ 0.2146 and ¼ = 0.25, so you may take, for instance,  
        r = 0.23.

2.  Reach the circle |OP| = r.  
    From the centre swim straight out until your distance from O is r (this takes the
    tiger no closer to you, because while you are moving directly away from O the
    tiger, who is outside the lake, can do nothing better than stay where he is).

3.  Swim round O on the circle |OP| = r until the tiger is diametrically opposite you.  

    •  Your angular speed about O is ω_m = v/r = 1/r.  
       With r = 0.23, ω_m ≈ 4.35.  
    •  The tiger, running on the bank of radius 1, has angular speed  
       ω_t = 4v/1 = 4.  

    Because ω_m > ω_t you can increase the angle between you and the tiger; in
    particular you can make that angle exactly π (180°).  
    While you are doing this the tiger continually adjusts his position, but the
    distance between you and the tiger (across the water) never falls below 1 – r > ¾,
    so you are in no immediate danger.

4.  Dash straight for the shore along the radius on which you now lie.  

    •  Distance you must swim: 1 – r.  
      Time you need: T_m = (1 – r)/v = 1 – r.  
      With r = 0.23, T_m = 0.77.  

    •  The tiger is on the opposite side of the lake; to reach your landing point
      it has to run half the circumference, a distance π.  
      Time the tiger needs: T_t = π/(4v) = π/4 ≈ 0.7854.

    Because 1 – r < π/4 by the choice of r, we have T_m < T_t.  
    Numerically, 0.77 < 0.7854, so you reach the bank a few hundredths of a time-unit
    before the tiger.

Hence the tiger arrives too late to catch you, and you are safe.

The essential facts are

•  If you keep inside the circle of radius ¼ your angular speed exceeds the tiger’s,
   so you can place him where you want on the rim.

•  Choosing any r with 1 – π/4 < r < ¼ guarantees that the radial dash to the shore
   is completed sooner than the tiger can cover the required half-circumference.

Final answer: Swim in a small circle of radius slightly less than ¼ until the tiger is exactly opposite you, then swim straight to the bank; you reach land before the tiger can run halfway round the shore, so you escape.

Question: Justin has a bag of marbles and nine friends.  He gives Mike exactly 1/2 of the marbles.  He gives Paul exactly 1/3 of the remaining marbles.  He gives Dave exactly 1/4 of the remaining marbles.  He gives Bert exactly 1/5 of the remaining marbles.  He gives Kyle exactly 1/6 of the remaining marbles.  He gives Andy 1/7 of the remaining marbles.  He gives Rick 1/8 of the remaining marbles.  He gives Fred 1/9 of the remaining marbles.  He gives Will 1/10 of the remaining marbles.  What is the smallest quantity of marbles that Justin still has in the bag?
Hint: Think about how a least common multiple could be helpful
Human Solution:
For each friend that Justin gives marbles, you need to calculate the fraction of the original quantity of marbles that Justin keeps in his possession (keep), the fraction of the original quantity of marbles that Justin gives to that friend (give), and the prime factorization of the denominator of the fraction given to that friend (factor).
Mike: keep 1 * 1/2 = 1/2, give 1 * 1/2 = 1/2, factor 2 = 2
Paul: keep 1/2 * 2/3 = 1/3, give 1/2 * 1/3 = 1/6, factor 6 = 2 * 3
Dave: keep 1/3 * 3/4 = 1/4, give 1/3 * 1/4 = 1/12, factor 12 = 2 * 2 * 3
Bert: keep 1/4 * 4/5 = 1/5, give 1/4 * 1/5 = 1/20, factor 20 = 2 * 2 * 5
Kyle: keep 1/5 * 5/6 = 1/6, give 1/5 * 1/6 = 1/30, factor 30 = 2 * 3 * 5
Andy: keep 1/6 * 6/7 = 1/7, give 1/6 * 1/7 = 1/42, factor 42 = 2 * 3 * 7
Rick: keep 1/7 * 7/8 = 1/8, give 1/7 * 1/8 = 1/56, factor 56 = 2 * 2 * 2 * 7
Fred: keep 1/8 * 8/9 = 1/9, give 1/8 * 1/9 = 1/72, factor 72 = 2 * 2 * 2 * 3 * 3
Will: keep 1/9 * 9/10 = 1/10, give 1/9 * 1/10 = 1/90, factor 90 = 2 * 3 * 3 * 5
The lowest common multiple of the denominators of the "give" fractions is:
2 * 2 * 2 * 3 * 3 * 5 * 7 = 2520
The quantity of marbles that Justin still possesses is:
2520 * 1/10 = 252
Justin starts with 2520 marbles.
Mike gets 1/2 of 2520, or 1260.  Justin still has 1/2 of 2520, or 1260.
Paul gets 1/3 of 1260, or 420.  Justin still has 2/3 of 1260, or 840.
Dave gets 1/4 of 840, or 210.  Justin still has 3/4 of 840, or 630.
Bert gets 1/5 of 630, or 126.  Justin still has 4/5 of 630, or 504.
Kyle gets 1/6 of 504, or 84.  Justin still has 5/6 of 504, or 420.
Andy gets 1/7 of 420, or 60.  Justin still has 6/7 of 420, or 360.
Rick gets 1/8 of 360, or 45.  Justin still has 7/8 of 360, or 315.
Fred gets 1/9 of 315, or 35.  Justin still has 8/9 of 315, or 280.
Will gets 1/10 of 280, or 28.  Justin still has 9/10 of 280, or 252.
Response:
Let N be the number of marbles Justin starts with and let Rk be the number still in the bag after the k-th friend has been served.

Step-by-step behaviour of the bag  

Friend (fraction taken)  Marbles left  
Mike (½)         R₁ = N − N/2 = N/2  
Paul (⅓)         R₂ = R₁ − R₁/3 = (2/3)R₁ = N/3  
Dave (¼)         R₃ = (3/4)R₂ = N/4  
Bert (⅕)         R₄ = (4/5)R₃ = N/5  
Kyle (⅙)         R₅ = (5/6)R₄ = N/6  
Andy (⅐)         R₆ = (6/7)R₅ = N/7  
Rick (⅛)         R₇ = (7/8)R₆ = N/8  
Fred (⅑)         R₈ = (8/9)R₇ = N/9  
Will (¹⁄₁₀)        R₉ = (9/10)R₈ = N/10  

Hence, after all nine friends are served, Justin retains exactly N/10 marbles.

Divisibility conditions for the process to use whole marbles

1. N must be divisible by 2 (for the ½ to be integral).  
2. R₁ = N/2 must be divisible by 3  ⇒ N divisible by 2·3 = 6.  
3. R₂ = N/3 must be divisible by 4  ⇒ N divisible by 3·4 = 12.  
4. R₃ = N/4 must be divisible by 5  ⇒ N divisible by 4·5 = 20.  
5. R₄ = N/5 must be divisible by 6  ⇒ N divisible by 5·6 = 30.  
6. R₅ = N/6 must be divisible by 7  ⇒ N divisible by 6·7 = 42.  
7. R₆ = N/7 must be divisible by 8  ⇒ N divisible by 7·8 = 56.  
8. R₇ = N/8 must be divisible by 9  ⇒ N divisible by 8·9 = 72.  
9. R₈ = N/9 must be divisible by 10 ⇒ N divisible by 9·10 = 90.

Therefore N must be a common multiple of
2, 6, 12, 20, 30, 42, 56, 72, 90.

Compute their least common multiple:

2 = 2  
6 = 2·3  
12 = 2²·3  
20 = 2²·5  
30 = 2·3·5  
42 = 2·3·7  
56 = 2³·7  
72 = 2³·3²  
90 = 2·3²·5  

The highest powers of the primes involved are  
2³, 3², 5¹, 7¹.

So LCM = 2³·3²·5·7 = 8·9·5·7 = 2520.

Thus the smallest possible initial number of marbles is 2520; consequently the smallest possible number Justin can still have is

R₉ = N/10 = 2520/10 = 252.

Final answer: 252

Question:
Arrogant Arnold and Witty Will are brothers. One day, they were going from New Jersey to Florida. Bored, they decided to ask each other brain teasers. After a while, they got bored with this, so Arnold decided to place a bet. He would ask Will one teaser, which he thought was very hard. If Will got it right, Arnold would clean his room for the rest of the year. However, if Will got it WRONG, he would have to clean Arnold's room for a year and do his dishes for a month. After thinking for a while, Will agreed to this. This was Arnold's teaser:
Use each digit 1-9 only once each, so that one number multiplied by another equals the third. One example is 12*483=5796. Name at least one more!!!
Being witty as his name suggests, Will easily answered this. The question is, can you find one?
Hint:
1) They can't be -12*483=-5796, 1.2*48.3=57.96, etc.
2) The third number in another possibility is also 5796.
Response:
We must build three positive integers that

• together use every digit 1-9 exactly once (no zeros), and  
• satisfy “first × second = third”.

How many digits can the three numbers have?

Let the two factors have a and b digits and the product have c digits.  
We need a + b + c = 9.

Because the product of two numbers having at least two digits already exceeds 99, c cannot be 2; if both factors had three digits, their product would have at least five digits; hence the only feasible split is

a = 2, b = 3, c = 4.              (2-digit) × (3-digit) = (4-digit)

Step 1.  Use divisibility by 9  
The sum of the nine different digits 1+2+…+9 = 45 is divisible by 9, so the product itself must be divisible by 9.  Therefore at least one of the two factors must be a multiple of 9.  It is simplest to make the 2-digit factor a multiple of 9.

Among the two-digit multiples of 9 that do not repeat a digit and contain no 0 we have  
18, 27, 36, 45, 54, 63, 72, 81.

Step 2.  Choose the final digit of the product  
Since no factor may contain a 0 or a 5, the only convenient way to obtain a final digit 5 or 0 in the product is impossible, so let the product end in 6 (a very common final digit: 2×3, 2×8, 4×4, 7×8 … all give 6).

If the 2-digit factor ends in 7, multiplying by a number that ends in 8 gives the desired last-digit pattern 7 × 8 ≡ 6 (mod 10).  
Hence pick the 2-digit factor 27 and let the 3-digit factor end in 8.

Step 3.  Finish the 3-digit factor  
The digits 2 and 7 are used, leaving 1,3,4,5,6,8,9.  To ensure the 3-digit factor is divisible by 9 (so the whole product is divisible by 81), its digit-sum must be a multiple of 9.  With the ending 8, selecting 1 and 9 gives 1+9+8 = 18, indeed a multiple of 9.  Thus choose the 3-digit factor 198.

Step 4.  Verify the multiplication and digit-usage  
27 × 198 = 5346

Digits used:  
27 → 2,7  
198 → 1,9,8  
5346 → 5,3,4,6  

All nine digits 1-9 appear exactly once, with none repeated and none omitted.  Therefore the construction is valid.

We have produced the required new pandigital identity.

Final answer: 27 × 198 = 5346

Question: In the equation FORTY+TEN+TEN=SIXTY, each letter represents a different digit. Can you figure out which letter is which digit?
Hint: Start from the last digits.
Human Solution:
First, there are ten different letters in this equation: E, F, I, N, O, R, S, T, X, Y. Therefore, every digit from 0 to 9 is used.
Because the last two digits of TY+EN*2 is TY, EN*2 is divisible by 100, EN must equal 50.
We get FOR+T*2+1=SIX.
Since T*2+1<20, SI is at most FO+2. We must have S=F+1, and since the digit 0 is occupied by N, O must equal 9 and I must equal 1. Hence SI=FO+2.
We get R+T*2+1=20+X, or R=X+(19-T*2). The remaining digits are 2, 3, 4, 6, 7, 8.
If T=6, Then R=X+7, which is impossible for these numbers. And T can't be lower.
If T=7, then R=X+5, and we can only have R=8, X=3. This leaves 2, 4, 6, from which we can't choose S=F+1.
If T=8, then R=X+3, we can have R=6, X=3, or R=7, X=4.
If R=6, X=3, the remaining digits are 2, 4, 7, and again we can't choose S=F+1.
If R=7, X=4, the remaining digits are 2, 3, 6, where 3=2+1. Hence S=3, F=2.
Finally, the remaining digit 6 is for Y.
Therefore, the equation is 29786+850+850=31486.
Response:
Write the addends under one another so that units, tens, hundreds … line up.

            F O R T Y
          +     T E N
          +     T E N
          --------------
            S I X T Y

Treat every column separately, carrying when necessary.

1.  Units column  
   Y + N + N = Y  (mod 10).  
   Hence 2N ≡ 0 (mod 10) → N = 0 or 5.

2.  Tens column  
   T + E + E + carry₁ = T  (mod 10).  
   So 2E + carry₁ ≡ 0 (mod 10).

   • If N = 5, carry₁ = 1, so 2E + 1 ≡ 0 (mod 10) ⇒ 2E ≡ 9, impossible.  
   • Therefore N = 0, carry₁ = 0 and 2E ≡ 0 (mod 10) ⇒ E = 5.

   The tens-column total is 2E = 10, so carry₂ = 1.

3.  Hundreds column  
   R + T + T + carry₂ = X + 10·carry₃  
   ⇒ R + 2T + 1 = X + 10·carry₃.          (1)

4.  Thousands column  
   O + carry₃ = I + 10·carry₄.            (2)

5.  Ten-thousands column  
   F + carry₄ = S.                        (3)

From (3) F and S are consecutive digits, so carry₄ = 1 and S = F + 1.

Thus (2) must create that carry, so carry₃ ≠ 0.  
Because carry₃ ≤ 2 (the maximum possible in (1)), carry₃ = 2 gives the required carry, and (2) forces O = 9 and I = 1.

Substitute carry₃ = 2 in (1):

          R + 2T + 1 = X + 20
   ⇒      X = R + 2T – 19, 19 ≤ R + 2T ≤ 28.          (4)

Digits already used: 0(N), 1(I), 5(E), 9(O).  
Digits still available: 2,3,4,6,7,8.

Search the limited possibilities allowed by (4):

T = 6 → R + 12 in {19…28} ⇒ R = 7 or 8.  
 • R = 7 ⇒ X = 0 (already N) impossible.  
 • R = 8 ⇒ X = 1 (already I) impossible.

T = 7 → R + 14 in {19…28} ⇒ R = 6 or 8.  
 • R = 6 ⇒ X = 1 (already I) impossible.  
 • R = 8 ⇒ X = 3  (all digits distinct) … candidate.

T = 8 → R + 16 in {19…28} ⇒ R = 3,4,6,7.  
 • R = 3 ⇒ X = 0 (already N) impossible.  
 • R = 4 ⇒ X = 1 (already I) impossible.  
 • R = 6 ⇒ X = 3 (already unused) … candidate.  
 • R = 7 ⇒ X = 4 … candidate.

Now satisfy S = F + 1 with unused digits:

Candidate 1:  T=7, R=8, X=3 uses digits 0,1,3,5,7,8,9.  
   Remaining digits 2,4,6 for {F,S,Y}.  
   F can be 2 (S=3 clashes with X), 4 (S=5 clashes with E), 6 (S=7 clashes with T).  
   No choice works → reject.

Candidate 2:  T=8, R=6, X=3 uses 0,1,3,5,6,8,9.  
   Remaining digits 2,4,7.  
   F=2 gives S=3 (clashes with X); F=4 gives S=5 (clashes with E); F=7 gives S=8 (clashes with T).  
   Reject.

Candidate 3:  T=8, R=7, X=4 uses 0,1,4,5,7,8,9.  
   Remaining digits 2,3,6.  
   F = 2 ⇒ S = 3 (both unused) and Y = 6.  All ten digits are now different – success.

Thus

F = 2,  O = 9,  R = 7,  T = 8,  Y = 6,
E = 5,  N = 0,  S = 3,  I = 1,  X = 4.

Check:

   FORTY   = 29786  
   TEN     =   850  
   TEN     =   850  
             ——–––  
   SIXTY   = 31486

Addition holds exactly.

Final answer: F = 2, O = 9, R = 7, T = 8, Y = 6, E = 5, N = 0, S = 3, I = 1, X = 4

Question: Two cars race around a circular track, in opposite directions, at constant rates. They start at the same point and meet every 30 seconds. If they move in the same direction, they meet every 120 seconds. If the track is 1800 meters long, what is the speed of each car?
Hint:
1)
Let  x = rate of car 1 (m/s)
Let y = rate of car 2  (m/s)
1800m = 30x+30y
1800-30x = 30y
2) Use method of substitution or elimination.
Human Solution:
Let  x = rate of car 1 (m/s)
Let y = rate of car 2  (m/s)
(1)  1800m = 30x+30y
1800-30x = 30y
7200-120x = 120y
(2)  1800 + 120x = 120y
Solve for Car 1: (1)=(2)
7200-120x = 1800+120x
5400 = 240x
x = 22.5 m/s
Convert to km/hr
x = 22.5m/sec *60sec/min*60min/hr = 81 km/hr
1000 m/km
Solve for Car 2:
Substitute x = 22.5 m/s
1800+120x = 120y
y = 1800+120x
120
y = 1800+120(22.5)
120
y = 37.5 m/s
Convert to km/hr
x =37.5m/sec *60sec/min*60min/hr = 135 km/hr
1000 m/km
Response:
Let  

 v₁  = speed of Car 1 (m s⁻¹)  
 v₂  = speed of Car 2 (m s⁻¹)  

and let  

 L = length of the circular track = 1800 m.

-------------------------------------------------
1. Cars travelling in opposite directions
-------------------------------------------------
Moving in opposite directions, their relative speed is v₁ + v₂.

Because they start together, the first time they coincide again is when their
relative motion has carried one car exactly one full circumference ahead of the
other, i.e. after they have “closed” a distance L.

Period between consecutive meetings  
 T₁ = L / (v₁ + v₂).

Given that they meet every 30 s,

 L / (v₁ + v₂) = 30  
 ⇒ v₁ + v₂ = L / 30 = 1800 / 30 = 60 m s⁻¹. (1)

-------------------------------------------------
2. Cars travelling in the same direction
-------------------------------------------------
With both cars going the same way, the faster car overtakes the slower one.
Their relative speed is |v₁ − v₂|, and one full circumference of gain is needed
for an overtaking to occur.

Period between consecutive overtakes  
 T₂ = L / |v₁ − v₂|.

Given that they meet every 120 s,

 L / |v₁ − v₂| = 120  
 ⇒ |v₁ − v₂| = L / 120 = 1800 / 120 = 15 m s⁻¹. (2)

Without loss of generality let v₁ > v₂, so v₁ − v₂ = 15.

-------------------------------------------------
3. Solving for the individual speeds
-------------------------------------------------
From (1): v₁ + v₂ = 60  
From (2): v₁ − v₂ = 15

Add: 2v₁ = 75 ⇒ v₁ = 37.5 m s⁻¹  
Substitute: v₂ = 60 − 37.5 = 22.5 m s⁻¹

-------------------------------------------------
4. Expressing the answers
-------------------------------------------------
37.5 m s⁻¹ = 37.5 × 3.6 = 135 km h⁻¹  
22.5 m s⁻¹ = 22.5 × 3.6 = 81 km h⁻¹

Final answer: Car 1 travels at 37.5 m/s (135 km/h) and Car 2 travels at 22.5 m/s (81 km/h).

Question: A man has nine children born at regular intervals. The sum of the square of their ages is equal to the square of his own age. What are the ages of his children?
Hint: The youngest children are very young
Human Solution: You can basically use two parameters--the age of the youngest child and the age difference. Then, toggle with these two things and see if the sum of squares is a square. The ages are 2,5,8,11,14,17,20,23 and 26. The man's age is 48.
Response:
Let the nine children be  

a , a+d , a+2d , … , a+8d  (d>0, the common interval, a≥0).  

Let the father’s present age be F.  
According to the statement  

(1) (a)^2+(a+d)^2+⋯+(a+8d)^2 = F^2 .

1.  Write the left–hand side in closed form.  
 Σ_{k=0}^{8}(a+kd)^2  
 = 9a^2+72ad+204d^2 .

2.  Complete the square in a.  
 9a^2+72ad+204d^2 = 9(a+4d)^2 + 60d^2.  
Put  

 p = a+4d  (so a = p−4d).  

Then

(2) F^2 = 9p^2 + 60d^2 .

3.  Factor (2).  
 F^2 – (3p)^2 = 60d^2  
 ⇒ (F−3p)(F+3p) = 60d^2.                    (3)

4.  Determine the parity of the factors.  
The two factors on the left differ by 6p, hence they have the same parity.  
Because their product is divisible by 3, each is divisible by 3; write  

 F−3p = 6u, F+3p = 6v  (u,v positive, v>u).  

Then from (3)

 6u·6v = 60d^2  ⇒ uv = 15d^2.            (4)

5.  Remove the square–free part.  
Because 15 = 3·5 is square–free, (4) implies that d itself must contain the factor 3; write d = 3e (e>0).  
Then (4) becomes  

 uv = 15e^2.                                                 (5)

6.  Solve (5).  
The positive divisors of 15 are 1, 3, 5, 15.  Hence the possibilities for {u,v} (with u≤v) are

 {1,15}, {3,5}.  

(The larger sets that appear when e≥2 give rise to father’s ages far beyond the children-bearing span and will be discussed later.)

7.  Use the first possibility u = 1, v = 15, with e = 1.  
Then

 d = 3e = 3,  
 F = 3(u+v) = 3·16 = 48,  
 p = v−u = 14,  
 a = p−4d = 14 − 12 = 2.

Thus the children are

 2, 5, 8, 11, 14, 17, 20, 23, 26 years old.

A check:

 2^2+5^2+8^2+11^2+14^2+17^2+20^2+23^2+26^2  
 = 4+25+64+121+196+289+400+529+676  
 = 2304 = 48^2 = F^2.

8.  Why the other formal solutions are rejected.  
With d = 3e = 6, 9, … (obtained by taking e ≥ 2 or the second factor-pair {3,5}) one gets father’s ages 96, 144, … and intervals of 6, 9, … years between births; the nine births would have to extend over 48, 72, … years, which is biologically impossible for a single set of parents.  Hence the only admissible integral solution is the one just found.

Therefore the ages of the nine children are

2, 5, 8, 11, 14, 17, 20, 23 and 26 years.

Final answer: 2, 5, 8, 11, 14, 17, 20, 23, 26

Question:
Mad Ade was visiting his friend, computer tycoon and Olympic Kebab hurling champion, Mike Rohsopht.
He was there on Sunday and when the radio gave the time at the hour, Mad Ade noticed that the Madadian antique clock, designed by Madadian clock maker Arthur Minit (teaser #4891) was exactly 3 minutes slow.
"It loses 7 minutes every hour," said Mad Ade's friend. "No more and no less, but I've gotten used to it that way."
When Mad Ade spent a second evening with Mike Rohsopht later that same month, he remarked on the fact that the clock was dead right by radio time at the hour.
It was rather late in the evening, but Mike assured Mad Ade that his treasured Arthur Minit clock had not been adjusted nor fixed since his last visit.
What day of the week was Mad Ade's second visit?
Hint: It must lose some multiple of 12 hours in total
Human Solution:
The answer is 17 days and 3 hours later, which would have been a Wednesday.
This is the only other time in the same month when the two would agree at all.
In 17 days the slow clock loses 17*24*7 minutes = 2856 minutes, or 47 hours and 36 minutes.  In 3 hours more it loses 21 minutes, so it has lost a total of 47 hours and 57 minutes.  Modulo 12 hours, it has "gained" 3 minutes so as to make up the 3 minutes it was slow on Sunday.  It is now (fortnight plus 3 days) exactly accurate.
Since the clock was not adjusted since the last visit, it's also possible that the radio time shifted by one hour due to a change to or from summer daylight saving time.  However, it turns out that the only additional possibilities that need to be considered are those of 4 days 15 hours later, when the clock would have lost 12 hours 57 minutes, and 29 days 15 hours later, when the clock would have lost 3 days 10 hours 57 minutes.  Without even considering the rules for when in the month the
clock is changed, these possible solutions are ruled out because we know that both visits were in the evening ("Mad Ade spent a second evening with Mike Rohsopht") and they involve times in a different part of the day.
Response:
Let the radio give the exact hour at the moment of the first visit (on a Sunday).  
At that instant the Arthur Minit clock is 3 minutes slow.

1.  How the error grows  
   The clock loses 7 minutes every real hour.  
   After n real hours its total loss is  

            loss = 3 min + 7 n min.                       (1)

2.  When can the clock read the correct time again?  
   The hands of an ordinary 12-hour dial repeat every 12 hours = 720 minutes.  
   Thus the loss in (1) must equal an integer number k of full 12-hour turns:

            3 + 7 n = 720 k,    with k ∈ ℤ.              (2)

3.  Solving for n  
   Because gcd(7, 720)=1, equation (2) has a unique solution for n modulo 720.  
   Multiplying by the inverse of 7 modulo 720 (7·103 = 721 ≡ 1) gives  

            n ≡ 3·103 ≡ 309   (mod 720).

   The smallest positive integral n is therefore  

            n = 309 hours.                                (3)

4.  Converting 309 hours  
            309 h = 12 days + 21 hours.

   So the second coincidence of clock and radio occurs exactly 12 days 21 hours after the first.

5.  What day of the week is that?  
   Twelve days advance the calendar by 1 week + 5 days:  

            Sunday → Friday.                              (4)

   The extra 21 hours do not reach a full additional day provided the first observation was made no later than 2 a.m., and the story tells us the second meeting was “rather late in the evening”.  
   (If the first check had been after 3 a.m., the 21-hour surplus would push the time into Saturday morning, contradicting the “late evening” description.)

   Hence the second visit took place on the same civil day reached in (4).

Final answer: Friday

Question: Pretend you have two faucets for your shower, one that releases hot water and one that releases cold water, but at varying pressures.  If the hot water is 105 degrees Fahrenheit and the cold water is 45 degrees Fahrenheit, and you could rotate the faucet at most 360 degrees, how much would you have to rotate the cold water faucet to get the temperature to be 98.6 degrees Fahrenheit, if the hot water is turned on all the way, and could not be turned down?
Hint: Add how much you've rotated each and divide by the total rotation to get the average temperature.
Human Solution:
the equation for finding the answer, explained by the hint, is              (105(360)+(45)(x))/(360+x)=98.6
Solving for x:
x= 42.985 degrees
Response:
Let  

Tₕ = 105 °F  (hot–water temperature, faucet fully open)  
T𝚌 = 45 °F   (cold–water temperature)  

Denote by H the (fixed) volumetric flow rate of the hot water when its faucet is wide-open, and by C the flow rate of the cold water.  When the cold faucet is turned from shut-off to fully open it can rotate 360°, and we assume its flow rate is directly proportional to the angle θ (in degrees) through which it is turned.  Hence

C = (θ / 360°) H.

(The constant of proportionality is H because at θ = 360° both faucets would deliver the same maximum flow rate H.)

The mixed water temperature T that comes out of the shower is the weighted average of the two streams:

T = (H Tₕ + C T𝚌) / (H + C).

Substitute C = (θ/360) H and the numerical temperatures:

T = [H·105 + (θ/360)H·45] / [H + (θ/360)H]
   = (105 + 45 θ/360) / (1 + θ/360).

We want T to equal normal body temperature, 98.6 °F:

(105 + 45 θ/360) / (1 + θ/360) = 98.6.

Let x = θ/360.  Then

105 + 45x = 98.6(1 + x)  
105 + 45x = 98.6 + 98.6x  
105 – 98.6 = 98.6x – 45x  
6.4 = 53.6x  
x = 6.4 / 53.6 = 8 / 67.

Therefore

θ = 360 x = 360·(8/67) = 2880/67 ≈ 42.99°.

So the cold-water handle must be opened by roughly 43 degrees from the shut-off position.

Final answer: about 43° of rotation of the cold-water faucet.

Question:
If you add 9 and 9 you get 18, and if you multiply 9 by 9 you get 81 (the reverse of 18). There are 2 more pairs of numbers with the same characteristics and where the result is two-digit:
24 + 3 = 27 and 24 * 3 = 72
and
47 + 2 = 49 and 47 * 2 = 94
But there is only one pair of numbers with a triple-digit result and its reversion.
What are the 2 numbers?
Hint: One number has 1 digit and the other has 3.
Human Solution:
The numbers are 497 and 2:
497 + 2 = 499
and
497 * 2 = 994
Response:
Let the two positive integers be x ≥ y.

1.  Denote their sum by  
       S = x + y   ( three–digit : 100 ≤ S ≤ 999 )

    and let R be the reversal of S, i.e.  
       R = rev(S).

    The condition of the problem is  

          x + y = S ,      x · y = R .                (1)

2.  A first bound for y  
    Since R ≤ 999 and x ≥ y we have y² ≤ xy = R ≤ 999, so y ≤ 31.  
    A sharper bound is obtained from (1):

          y(S – y) = R ≤ 999  ⇒  y(100 – y) ≤ 999 .

    For y = 12 the left–hand side is 12·88 = 1056 > 999,  
    hence y ≤ 11.  Thus

          1 ≤ y ≤ 11.                                     (2)

3.  Writing S with its digits  
       S = 100a + 10b + c  (a ≠ 0 , a,b,c ∈ {0,…,9}) ,

    its reversal is  
       R = 100c + 10b + a.

    Substituting these expressions in (1) gives

          y(100a + 10b + c) – (100c + 10b + a) = y².      (3)

    Rearranging,

          a(100y – 1) + b·10(y – 1) + c(y – 100) = y².    (4)

    For every integer y in the range (2) we must decide whether
    (4) admits digits a,b,c.

4.  Eliminating the impossible values of y  

    y = 1 :   99(a – c) = 1      impossible.  

    y = 2 :   199a + 10b – 98c = 4.  
              Trying a = 4 (even, necessary for parity) gives  
              199·4 + 10b – 98·9 = 4 → 796 + 10b – 882 = 4 → 10b = 90 → b = 9.  
              Digits (a,b,c) = (4,9,9) satisfy the equation.  
              Hence S = 499,   R = 994, and the numbers are

                     x = S – y = 499 – 2 = 497 ,   y = 2.           (5)

    y = 3 :   299a + 20b – 97c = 9  ⇒  no solution in digits.  

    y = 4 :   399a + 30b – 96c = 16 ; the left side is divisible by 3,
              the right side is not  ⇒  impossible.

    y = 5 :   499a + 40b – 95c = 25 ; modulo 5 forces a = 5,
              which leads to b negative  ⇒  impossible.

    y = 6 :   599a + 50b – 94c = 36 ; divisibility by 50 fails  ⇒  impossible.

    y = 7 :   699a + 60b – 93c = 49 ; left side ≡ 0 (mod 3), right side ≡ 1  ⇒  impossible.

    y = 8 :   799a + 70b – 92c = 64 ; divisibility by 70 fails  ⇒  impossible.

    y = 9 :   899a + 80b – 91c = 81 ; modulo 10 gives c = 9a – 1,
              which leads to b non-integral  ⇒  impossible.

    y = 10 :  999a + 90b – 90c = 100 ; left side ≡ 0 (mod 9), right side ≡ 1  ⇒  impossible.

    y = 11 :  1099a + 100b – 89c = 121 ; modulo 10 gives a – c ≡ 9,
              no admissible b  ⇒  impossible.

5.  Conclusion  
    The only value of y that works is y = 2, giving S = 499 and R = 994, i.e.

          497 + 2 = 499 ,    497 × 2 = 994 ,

    the product being exactly the reversal of the sum.

Therefore the unique pair required in the problem is

Final answer: 497 and 2

Question:
12 is an abundant number, because the sum of its proper divisors: 1+2+3+4+6=16, and this is larger than the number itself. However, you will notice that 1+2+3+6=12.
A weird number is an abundant number, n, for which no subset of its proper divisors adds to n. What is the smallest weird number?
Hint: They are very rare indeed. The smallest is somewhere between 50 and 100.
Human Solution:
The number needs a lot of prime factors for the sum to exceed the number--a factor of 2 is pretty important to get a large enough factor, and then the next prime factor being at least 5 is good so the small primes are less granular and the sum might only barely exceed th number; The smallest weird number is 70.
The next three being 836, 4030 and 5830.
Response:
For each natural number n let σ(n) be the sum of all proper divisors of n
(the divisors different from n itself).

1.  Definitions  
   – n is abundant ⇔ σ(n) > n.  
   – n is weird      ⇔ n is abundant and no sub-collection of its proper
     divisors has sum n.

2.  The candidate 70  

   Proper divisors of 70 : 1 , 2 , 5 , 7 , 10 , 14 , 35  
   Their total is 74 > 70, so 70 is abundant.

   We must show that no subset of {1,2,5,7,10,14,35} adds up to 70.

   (i)  If 35 were present, the remaining divisors would have to
        contribute 35.  
        The largest sum obtainable from {1,2,5,7,10,14} is  
        14+10+7+5+2+1 = 39, and every one of its subsums is
        39–k with k≥1, hence strictly below 35.
        Therefore no subset containing 35 totals 70.

   (ii) Hence 35 is absent.  
        If 14 were present (with 35 absent) the biggest possible total
        would be 14+ (1+2+5+7+10)=39 < 70.  
        Therefore 14 is absent.

   (iii)  If 10 were present (with 35,14 absent) the largest possible
          total is 10+ (1+2+5+7)=25 < 70, so 10 is absent.

   (iv)  With 35,14,10 already excluded, the remaining divisors are
         {1,2,5,7}.  Their whole sum is 15 < 70.

   Consequently no subset of the proper divisors of 70 gives 70.
   Therefore 70 is weird.

3.  No smaller number can be weird  

   Every abundant integer below 70 has a subset of its proper divisors
   whose sum equals the number itself (a short exhibit is given).

   12 : 1+2+3+6=12  
   18 : 9+6+3=18  
   20 : 10+5+4+1=20  
   24 : 12+8+4=24  
   30 : 15+10+5=30  
   36 : 18+9+6+3=36  
   40 : 20+10+8+2=40  
   42 : 21+14+7=42  
   48 : 24+16+8=48  
   54 : 27+18+9=54  
   56 : 28+14+8+4+2=56  
   60 : 30+20+10=60  
   66 : 33+22+11=66  

   Since all abundant numbers less than 70 are therefore
   non-weird, 70 is indeed the smallest weird number.

Final answer: 70

Question: On planet ?*!@, the inhabitants are robots with various numbers of arms. The robots are grouped into tribes according to the numbers of arms they have so that in any tribe, no member has a different number of arms to the other members. Each tribe follows the same fertility ritual before bed each night, a ritual that also reveals the number of members in a tribe. In the ritual, each arm of a male links with an arm of a female, no male-female pair of robots linking more than once. The minimum number of robots required to link all arms once only is the number belonging to that tribe. Now one night, the Creaky tribe cornered half of the Rusty tribe and despite being outnumbered two to one, unscrewed one arm from each, there being an equal number of male and female victims. However, the Creaky tribe were extremely poor at arithmetic and had failed to realise that they needed 24 times their actual haul of spare arms in order that the number of links their members could then make, each with the same number of extra arms, was half the maximum number of links the Rusty tribe could then make. How many Creakies and Rusties were there?
Human Solution: ARMLESS ALIENS. There were 14 Creakies and 56 Rusties. A robot with n arms requires n females and vice-versa, and the number of members is 2n with n squared links. Let the Creaky tribe have x arms each and the Rusty tribe have y. Then the maximum number of links that the Rusty tribe can make after the mutilation is y(2y-1)/2. The number of extra arms each Creaky needs is 24y/2x allowing x(x + 24y/2x) links. Forming the links equation we have 2(y squared) - 49y - 4(x squared) = 0. We must have y=4x so that y - 4x is a factor. A long division shows that the condition for zero remainder is x=7 so y=28. The numbers of members are twice these.
Response:
Let  

 x = number of arms on each Creaky robot  
 y = number of arms on each Rusty robot  

Because every tribe contains the least possible number of robots that allows all arms to be linked once (no pair of robots linking more than once), a tribe with k-armed robots must contain exactly 2k robots (k males, k females).  

Hence  
 number of Creakies  C = 2x,  
 number of Rusties R = 2y.  (1)

The raid  
Half of the Rusty tribe (R/2 robots) was cornered.  
Creakies were “out-numbered two to one”, so

 R/2 = 2C  ⇒ R = 4C.  (2)

Using (1) in (2):

 2y = 4(2x) ⇒ y = 4x.  (3)

The haul of arms  
Each of the R/2 = y captured Rusties lost one arm, so the Creakies obtained  

 S = y  spare arms.  (4)

They intend to redistribute extra arms so that every Creaky gets the same number of extras.  
With their real haul they are short by a factor 24; they would need 24S arms.  
Let a be the common number of extra arms each Creaky would then receive.  Then  

 (2x)·a = 24S = 24y.  (5)

Substituting (3) and (4) into (5):

 2x·a = 24·(4x)  ⇒ a = 48.  (6)

Thus, equipped as intended, every Creaky would have x + 48 arms.

Maximum links after the raid  
•  Creakies (with enough spare arms)  
 number of males = number of females = x  
 arms per robot  = x + 48  
 maximum links   = x(x + 48).  (7)

•  Rusties  
They still number 2y robots (y males, y females).  
The y captured robots (y/2 males, y/2 females) each lost one arm.

Total male arms after the loss  
 = y·y − (y/2) = y^2 − y/2.  
With y = 4x, this is 16x^2 − 2x.  
Female arms are the same, so Rusties’ maximum links are

 16x^2 − 2x.  (8)

Condition given in the problem  
Creakies’ links (7) must equal one half of Rusties’ links (8):

 x(x + 48) = ½(16x^2 − 2x)  
 x^2 + 48x = 8x^2 − x  
 7x^2 − 49x = 0  
 x(x − 7) = 0.

Since x > 0, we get  

 x = 7.  (9)

Consequences  
From (3): y = 4x = 28.  
From (1):

 C = 2x = 14,  R = 2y = 56.

Verification  
• Half the Rusties = 28, twice the 14 Creakies.  
• Arms captured S = 28; 24S = 672 arms give each Creaky 48 extras (672/14 = 48).  
• Creakies could then make 7·55 = 385 links.  
• Rusties, after losing 28 arms, can make 16·7^2 − 2·7 = 770 links.  
 Indeed 385 = ½·770.

All conditions are satisfied.

Final answer: 14 Creakies and 56 Rusties.

Question:
Mad Ade's kids, Mad Ade junior and little Miss Mad Ade were going to cut the grass on their square lawn, while their dad was out buying a bumper family sized kebab with extra grease. They agreed that each should cut one-half of the area. Junior went first, and cut a border 2 metres wide all the way around.
After doing a few sums, Little Miss agreed that exactly one-half had been cut and happily cut the rest.
What was the area of the lawn?
Hint: set a mathematical equation by putting the area/dimensions of the whole lawn in terms of the area/dimensions of what little Miss Maddie has to mow
Human Solution: set a mathematical equation by putting the area/dimensions of the whole lawn in terms of the area/dimensions of what little Miss Maddie has to mow -- Area of lawn was 186.51 square metres
Response:
Let the lawn be a square with side s metres, so its total area is s².

Junior mows a strip 2 m wide all round the edge.  
After removing 2 m from each side, the remaining (un-cut) inner square has side

 s – 2 – 2 = s – 4 metres.

Hence

area cut by Junior  
 = original area – inner square area  
 = s² – (s – 4)².

We are told this area is exactly one-half of the lawn, i.e.

 s² – (s – 4)² = ½ s².

Expand and simplify:

s² – (s² – 8s + 16) = ½ s²  
8s – 16 = ½ s²  
Multiply by 2: 16s – 32 = s²  
Bring all terms to one side: s² – 16s + 32 = 0.

Solve the quadratic:

s = [16 ± √(16² – 4·1·32)] / 2  
 = [16 ± √128] / 2  
 = [16 ± 8√2] / 2  
 = 8 ± 4√2.

Since the side must exceed 4 m (so that an inner square exists), take

s = 8 + 4√2 metres.

Thus the lawn’s area is

s² = (8 + 4√2)²  
 = 64 + 64√2 + 32  
 = 96 + 64√2 ≈ 186.5 m².

Final answer: the lawn’s area is 96 + 64√2 square metres (about 186.5 m²).

Question:
What is the largest number of pieces you can form with n straight cuts of a pizza?
The pieces do not need to be of equal size.
Hint: After j cuts, how many additional pieces can you cut with the (j+1)-th cut?
Human Solution:
The answer is n*(n+1)/2 + 1.
With every cut you should cut through every previous cut. As long as you keep doing this you will always be able to do so again with your next cut. The number of additional pieces formed on cut x will always be x. The sum of all integers from 1 to n is n*(n+1)/2. So the sum of additional pieces cut will be n*(n+1)/2.
Finally add 1 because we start with 1 piece: n*(n+1)/2 + 1.
Response:
Let P(n) be the greatest possible number of pieces a circular pizza can be cut into with n straight cuts.

Step 1.  Base case  
With 0 cuts the pizza remains whole, so  
P(0)=1.

Step 2.  How the nth cut can add pieces  
Assume we already have performed n−1 cuts in such a way that they produced the maximum number P(n−1) of pieces; in particular:  
• no two previous cuts are parallel, and  
• no three previous cuts meet at a single interior point.  

Place the nth cut so that it is not parallel to any earlier cut and does not pass through any earlier intersection point.  
Because of these two conditions the nth line meets every one of the n−1 previous lines in a distinct interior point, hence it is divided into n separate segments.  
Each of those segments lies inside a single existing piece of pizza and splits that piece into two.  
Consequently the nth cut increases the piece count by exactly n.

Therefore
P(n)=P(n−1)+n.       (recurrence relation)

Step 3.  Solve the recurrence  
Starting from P(0)=1,

P(1)=P(0)+1 = 2  
P(2)=P(1)+2 = 4  
P(3)=P(2)+3 = 7  
⋯  

Summing the increments gives
P(n)=1+1+2+3+⋯+n  
  =1+ n(n+1)/2.

Hence  

P(n)= (n²+n+2)/2.

Step 4.  Conclusion  
The largest possible number of pieces obtainable with n straight cuts is

P(n)= n(n+1)/2 + 1 = (n²+n+2)/2.

Final answer: (n²+n+2)/2

Question:
The following numbers are zingers:
9, 57, 41, 89, 33, and 17.
The following are not zingers:
2, 8, 59, 13, 68, and 36.
What is a zinger?
Hint: Think multiplication.
Human Solution: A zinger in this context is a number that is multiplied by eight and increased by one. For example, 8 x 2 = 16 and 16 + 1= 17.  Therefore 17 is a zinger.
Response:
Notice first that every “zinger’’ leaves the same remainder when divided by 8, while none of the “non-zingers’’ does.

Check the six given zingers:

9 ÷ 8 = 1 remainder 1  
57 ÷ 8 = 7 remainder 1  
41 ÷ 8 = 5 remainder 1  
89 ÷ 8 = 11 remainder 1  
33 ÷ 8 = 4 remainder 1  
17 ÷ 8 = 2 remainder 1  

Each of them is of the form 8k + 1; that is, each is congruent to 1 modulo 8.

Now examine the six numbers that are not zingers:

2 ≡ 2 (mod 8)  
8 ≡ 0 (mod 8)  
59 ≡ 3 (mod 8)  
13 ≡ 5 (mod 8)  
68 ≡ 4 (mod 8)  
36 ≡ 4 (mod 8)  

None of these is congruent to 1 modulo 8.

Since the given lists exhaust every residue class needed to test the hypothesis, the only consistent rule that separates the two groups is congruence to 1 mod 8.

Therefore:

Final answer: A zinger is any integer that is congruent to 1 modulo 8 (i.e., any number of the form 8k + 1).

Question:
You are in a food fight. An enemy is holding a hot sauce and will spray you with the fiery substance unless you answer the following question correctly:
A right cylinder, with a diameter congruent to its height is inscribed in a right cone with height 12 units and radius 5 units. If their axes coincide, find the radius of the cylinder.
Hint:
#1: By inscribed, your enemy means that the cylinder's whole bottom face is touching the cone's bottom face, and the cylinder is touching the cone with the circumference of the top face.
Hint #2: There are many ways to solve this, but a simple method is to imagine one triangle inside another.
Human Solution:
30/11. As mentioned in the hint, there are many methods in which to solve this. One less complex method is to imagine the axis of the cone form a right triangle. This triangle shares the dimensions of the cone, so it is 12 by 5. We are given that the diameter of the cylinder is congruent to the height, so we can deduce that the radius is half the length of the height. Imagine a radius that intersects the hypotenuse of the triangle discussed above. Let's call it x. Therefore, we get a right triangle with a smaller right triangle inside. Since two of the angles are the same (the top and the right angles), we can say that the two triangles are similar. Since the height of the cylinder is 2x (twice the length of the radius x), the height of the smaller right triangle is 12-2x. Thus, we can set up a proportion: 12/5 = 12-2x/x.
Next we can cross-multiply to get 12x=60-10x. If we add 10x on both sides, we get 22x=60, and dividing 22 from both sides yields x=60/22=30/11.
Response:
Let  

 r = radius of the cylinder  
 h = height of the cylinder.

Because “the diameter is congruent to the height,”  

 h = 2r. (1)

------------------------------------
1.  Place the cone and the cylinder
------------------------------------
Put the cone so that its apex is at the origin and its base is the plane z = 12.  
Let the common axis of cone and cylinder be the z–axis.

Because the cylinder is inscribed and the usual meaning of “inscribed in a cone” is that its lower base rests on the cone’s base, take

 • lower base of the cylinder: z = 12  
 • upper base of the cylinder: z = 12 – h.

------------------------------------
2.  Relate r to h with similar triangles
------------------------------------
At a height z above the apex, the cone’s radius is proportional to z:

 radius of cone at level z = (5 / 12) · z. (2)

At the level of the cylinder’s upper base (z = 12 – h) the cylinder must exactly fit the cone, so

 r = (5 / 12)(12 – h). (3)

------------------------------------
3.  Use h = 2r to solve for r
------------------------------------
Substitute (1) into (3):

 r = (5 / 12)(12 – 2r)  
 r = 5 – (5/6) r.

Move the r–terms to one side:

 r + (5/6) r = 5  
 (11/6) r = 5.

Hence

 r = 5 · (6/11) = 30/11.

------------------------------------
4.  Verification
------------------------------------
Height of cylinder: h = 2r = 60/11 < 12, so it lies completely inside the cone.

Upper-base level: z = 12 – h = 72/11.  
Cone’s radius there: (5/12)(72/11) = 30/11 = r, confirming the fit.

------------------------------------
Final answer: 30/11

Question: The year 1978 has an unusual property. When you add the 19 to the 78, the total is the same as the middle two digits (97). What will be the next year to have this same property?
Hint: Note that the hundreds digit must be at least as large as the sum of the thousands and tens digits... why?
Human Solution:
Note that the hundreds digit must be at least as large as the sum of the thousands and tens digits. -- then use this as a starting point and test hundreds digits for the smallest possible solutions The next year to have the same property will be 2307.
23 + 07 = 30
Response:
Let the four digits of the year be  

                     A   B   C   D  (thousands, hundreds, tens, units).

The property says

  (first two digits) + (last two digits) = (middle two digits),

that is  
  (10A + B) + (10C + D) = 10B + C.

Simplify:

  10A + B + 10C + D = 10B + C  
  10A – 9B + 9C + D = 0  
  9(B – C) = 10A + D.                                             (∗)

The left side is a multiple of 9, so 10A + D must also be a multiple of 9.

1.  A = 1  (the years 19 ##)  
  10A = 10.  To make 10A + D divisible by 9 we need D = 8 (since 10 + 8 = 18).  
  Then (∗) gives B – C = 18 / 9 = 2.  
  Thus the 1900-years that work are 1 B C 8 with B = C + 2:  

  1208, 1318, 1428, 1538, 1648, 1758, 1868, 1978.

  1978 is the last of these, so there is no later year in the 1900s with the property.

2.  A = 2  (the years 20 ##)  
  10A = 20.  For 20 + D to be divisible by 9 we need D = 7 (since 20 + 7 = 27).  
  Then (∗) gives B – C = 27 / 9 = 3.  
  So the 2000-years that work are 2 B C 7 with B = C + 3:

  2307, 2417, 2527, 2637, 2747, 2857, 2967.

The earliest of these is 2307, and it is later than 1978.

Check: 23 + 07 = 30, and the middle two digits of 2307 are indeed 30.

Hence, the first year after 1978 with the same property is

Final answer: 2307

Question:
Arrange the numerals "123456789" to form a 9-digit number (referred to as "ABCDEFGHI") whose 2-digit subsets meet the following criteria:
1) AB is divisible by 2
2) BC is divisible by 3
3) CD is divisible by 4
4) DE is divisible by 5
5) EF is divisible by 6
6) FG is divisible by 7
7) GH is divisible by 8
8) HI is divisible by 9
There are two solutions.
Hint: B, D, F, and H must be even
Human Solution:
781254963 and 187254963
AB, CD, EF, and GH must be divisible by even divisors.  Therefore B, D, F, and H must be even numerals.  This means that A, C, E, G, and I are odd numerals.  DE must be divisible by 5, therefore E is 5.  EF must be divisible by 6, therefore EF is 54.  FG must be divisible by 7, therefore FG is 49.  GH must be divisible by 8, therefore GH is 96.  GH must be divisible by 9, therefore GH is 63.  The last five digits have now been determined to be 54963.  To be divisible by 4, CD must end in 2.  This makes B equal 8.  The digits are now ?8?254963.  The remaining digits, 1 and 7, can be placed into either remaining location.
Response:
Let  
ABCDEFGHI be the required 9–digit number formed with the digits 1–9 once each.

1.  DE is to be divisible by 5 → the units digit of DE must be 5.  
   Hence E = 5.

2.  EF is to be divisible by 6 → F must be even and (E+F) divisible by 3.  
   With E = 5 the possibilities for an even F are 2, 4, 6, 8.

      5+2 = 7 (≡1 mod 3) not divisible by 3  
      5+4 = 9 (≡0 mod 3) works  
      5+6 = 11 (≡2 mod 3) no  
      5+8 = 13 (≡1 mod 3) no  

   Therefore F = 4, and EF = 54 is indeed divisible by 6.

3.  FG is to be divisible by 7.  
   54 leaves a remainder 5 when divided by 7, so 40 + G must be a multiple of 7.  
   40 ≡ 5 (mod 7) ⇒ G ≡ 2 (mod 7) ⇒ G = 2 or 9.

4.  GH is to be divisible by 8.  
   A 2–digit number 10G+H is divisible by 8 ⇔ 2G+H ≡ 0 (mod 8).

   • If G = 2, 2G = 4 and H ≡ 4 (mod 8) ⇒ H = 4 – impossible (F is already 4).  
   • Hence G = 9.  
     Then 2G = 18 ≡ –2 (mod 8) ⇒ H ≡ 6 (mod 8) ⇒ H = 6.

5.  HI is to be divisible by 9.  
   10H+I is divisible by 9 ⇔ H+I ≡ 0 (mod 9).  
   With H = 6 we need 6+I ≡ 0 (mod 9) ⇒ I = 3.

   Up to now we have  …E F G H I = …5 4 9 6 3.

6.  Digits used: 3,4,5,6,9.  Remaining digits for A,B,C,D: 1,2,7,8  
    (note B must be even because AB is to be divisible by 2).

7.  CD is to be divisible by 4.  Examine the pairs from {1,2,7,8}:

      12, 28, 72 are the only 2–digit numbers with distinct digits of the set
      that are divisible by 4.

   • Case 1: CD = 12 (C=1, D=2)  
       B must be the remaining even digit 8, and AB divisible by 2 holds.  
       BC = 81, and 8+1 = 9 ⇒ BC divisible by 3.  
       A is the remaining digit 7.  
       This gives 781254963.

   • Case 2: CD = 28 (C=2, D=8)  
       No even digit is left for B (2 and 8 already used), so impossible.

   • Case 3: CD = 72 (C=7, D=2)  
       B must again be 8.  BC = 87 with 8+7 = 15 divisible by 3.  
       A is the remaining digit 1.  
       This gives 187254963.

8.  Both candidates satisfy every condition:

      781254963 : 78,81,12,25,54,49,96,63  
      187254963 : 18,87,72,25,54,49,96,63  

   Each successive 2–digit block is divisible by 2,3,4,5,6,7,8,9 respectively.

Since all logical possibilities have been exhausted and only these two work, they are the only solutions.

Final answer: 781254963 and 187254963

Question:
The people of Olde Mathville had unique ways of punishing wayward citizens.   For example, those convicted of crimes of dishonesty were chained to the Liars' Rail until they solved a number of puzzles.
One such puzzle has been recently discovered!
In the multiplication below, each letter - L, I, A, R, and S - takes the place of a different digit.   Find the digits to make the multiplication true.
L I A R
x  S
--------
R A I L
or: L I A R  x  S  =  R A I L
Hint: The product of S x L must be less than 10.  Combining that with the need for S x R to end in L limits the possibilities quickly.
Human Solution:
L=2, I=1, A=7, R=8, and S=4
2178 x 4 = 8712
One possible solution guide:
* SxL<10, as the product is a 4-digit number; S can not = 1
... so S,L can be 2,3; 2,4; 3,1; 3,2; 4,1; 4,2
* but SxR ends in L - and if S or R is even, so is L
... so S,L,R can be 2,4,7; 3,1,7; 3,2,4; 4,2,8
* the first three are quickly rejected by checking the multiplication
... S=4, L=2, R=8
* Since 2000 x 4 = 8000, nothing has been carried from multiplying the hundreds digit
... so I=1 or 0
* I=0 is rejected as '3' tens have been carried forward from multiplying 4x8; the 3 must be added to 7 to give 0 in the bottom line, and we cannot have 4 x __ = 7.
... so I=1
... so A=7 (the only way to get a 1 in the tens column of the product)
Response:
Let  

 LIAR = 1000 L + 100 I + 10 A + R ,   
 RAIL = 1000 R + 100 A + 10 I + L ,   
 S = the one–digit multiplier.  

Multiplying LIAR by S digit–wise gives

 R S → units digit L, carry c₁  
 A S + c₁ → units digit I, carry c₂  
 I S + c₂ → units digit A, carry c₃  
 L S + c₃ = R  (no further carry, because the product has four digits)

This yields the system

(1) R S ≡ L (mod 10), c₁ = ⌊R S /10⌋  
(2) A S + c₁ ≡ I (mod 10), c₂ = ⌊(A S + c₁)/10⌋  
(3) I S + c₂ ≡ A (mod 10), c₃ = ⌊(I S + c₂)/10⌋  
(4) L S + c₃ = R                  

--------------------------------------------------------------------
1.  A bound for S

From (4) we need L S + c₃ ≤ 9.  As c₃ ≥ 0,  
  L S ≤ 9 ⇒ S ≤ ⌊9/L⌋.  

Hence

 L = 1  ⇒ S ≤ 9   
 L = 2  ⇒ S ≤ 4   
 L = 3  ⇒ S ≤ 3   
 L ≥ 4 ⇒ S ≤ 2.

Because all letters are different, S ≠ L and S ≠ 0.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
2.  The case L = 1

For L = 1 the congruence obtained from (1) and (4) is  

 S² + c₃S ≡ 1 (mod 10) with R = S + c₃ ≤ 9.

Trying S = 2,3,4,5,6,7,8,9 shows no value of c₃ (0 ≤ c₃ ≤ 9 − S)
gives the required residue 1; hence L = 1 is impossible.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
3.  The case L = 2

Then S ≤ 4 and S ≠ 2, so S = 3 or 4.

•  S = 3  

 R = 2·3 + c₃ = 6 + c₃ ≤ 9 ⇒ c₃ ≤ 3.   
 Equation (1): 3R ≡ 2 (mod 10) ⇒ 3(6 + c₃) ≡ 2 (mod 10)  
                ⇒ 3c₃ ≡ 4 (mod 10), impossible.  

 So S ≠ 3.

•  S = 4  

 R = 2·4 + c₃ = 8 + c₃ ≤ 9 ⇒ c₃ = 0 or 1.  
 Equation (1): 4R ≡ 2 (mod 10).

 If c₃ = 1, R = 9 and 4·9 ≡ 6 ≠ 2 (mod 10).  
 If c₃ = 0, R = 8 and 4·8 = 32 ≡ 2 (mod 10) – works.  
 Thus L = 2 , S = 4 , R = 8 , c₃ = 0.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
4.  Determining I, A and the remaining carries

With S = 4, c₁ = ⌊R S/10⌋ = ⌊32/10⌋ = 3.

Equations (2) and (3) become

 4A + 3 = 10c₂ + I      (2′)  
 4I + c₂ = A         (3′)

Substituting A from (3′) into (2′):

 4(4I + c₂) + 3 = 10c₂ + I  
 16I + 4c₂ + 3 = 10c₂ + I  
 15I + 3 = 6c₂  
 2c₂ = 5I + 1.                       (★)

Because 5I + 1 is even, I must be odd.  Testing odd digits ≠ 2,4,8:

 I = 1 ⇒ 2c₂ = 6 ⇒ c₂ = 3 (satisfies c₂ ≤ 3)  
 I = 3 ⇒ 2c₂ = 16 ⇒ c₂ = 8 (too large)  
 I ≥ 5 leads to c₂ ≥ 13 (impossible).

Hence I = 1 and c₂ = 3.  
Then from (3′): A = 4·1 + 3 = 7.

All letters are now distinct:  
 L = 2, I = 1, A = 7, R = 8, S = 4.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
5.  Verification

  2 1 7 8  
×     4  
────────────  
  8 7 1 2

The product 8712 indeed equals RAIL, the reverse of LIAR.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
Final answer: L = 2, I = 1, A = 7, R = 8, S = 4.

Question: Can you find a five digit number that, if you place a 9 at the beginning to make a new number, is four times larger than if you place the 9 at the end instead?
Hint: The first digit of this number must be 2
Response:
Let the required five–digit number be N.

1. When a 9 is placed at the front, the digits of N are merely shifted to the right by five places, so the new (six-digit) number is  
   9 × 10⁵ + N = 900 000 + N.

2. When a 9 is placed at the end, N is shifted left one place and 9 is added, giving  
   10N + 9.

3. The problem states that the first new number is four times the second:  
   900 000 + N = 4(10N + 9).

4. Solve for N:  
   900 000 + N = 40N + 36  
   900 000 – 36 = 39N  
   899 964 = 39N  
   N = 899 964 ÷ 39 = 23 076.

5. Check that N is indeed a five-digit number (23 076 lies between 10 000 and 99 999) and verify the condition:  
   • 9 at the front: 923 076.  
   • 9 at the end: 23 0769 = 230 769.  
   • 4 × 230 769 = 923 076, confirming the requirement.

Final answer: 23076

Question: I have a machine which has four cog wheels in constant mesh. The largest cog has 242 teeth and the others have 160, 64 and 22 respectively. How many revolutions must the largest cog make before each of the cogs is back in its starting position?
Hint: The least common multiple is helpful
Response:
Let  

N₁ = 242 , N₂ = 160 , N₃ = 64 , N₄ = 22   (numbers of teeth)  
x = number of revolutions made by the largest wheel (N₁).

For two gears in mesh the numbers of revolutions are in the inverse ratio of their teeth-numbers and their directions are opposite:

revolutions(A) / revolutions(B) = – N_B / N_A.

-------------------------------------------------
Step 1 – revolutions of the 160-tooth wheel  
r₂ = – N₁ / N₂ · x = – 242/160 · x = –121/80 · x.

-------------------------------------------------
Step 2 – revolutions of the 64-tooth wheel  
r₃ = – N₂ / N₃ · r₂  
     = –160/64 · (–121/80 · x)  
     = (160·121)/(64·80) · x = 121/32 · x.

-------------------------------------------------
Step 3 – revolutions of the 22-tooth wheel  
r₄ = – N₃ / N₄ · r₃  
     = –64/22 · (121/32 · x)  
     = –(64·121)/(22·32) · x = –11 · x.

-------------------------------------------------
Step 4 – condition for all wheels to return to their starting
positions  

Each wheel must turn an integer number of revolutions:

• r₂ = –121x/80 ∈ ℤ ⇒ 121x divisible by 80.  
• r₃ = 121x/32 ∈ ℤ ⇒ 121x divisible by 32.  
• r₄ = –11x      is integral whenever x is integral.

Because 121 is coprime to both 80 and 32, the divisibility
conditions reduce to

x divisible by 80 and by 32.

The least common multiple of 80 (2⁴·5) and 32 (2⁵) is  
LCM(80,32) = 2⁵·5 = 160.

Hence the smallest positive integer x satisfying the two conditions is

x = 160.

-------------------------------------------------
Conclusion  

After 160 revolutions of the 242-tooth cog, every wheel in the train
has completed an integral number of revolutions and is therefore back
in the exact orientation it had at the start.

Final answer: 160

Question: Three people (A, B, and C) need to cross a bridge. A can cross the bridge in 10 minutes, B can cross in 5 minutes, and C can cross in 2 minutes. There is also a bicycle available and any person can cross the bridge in 1 minute with the bicycle. What is the shortest time that all men can get across the bridge? Each man travels at their own constant rate.
Hint: The bicycle may be left at any point along the bridge and may be ridden in either direction. Every man should finish at the same time.
Human Solution:
A's speed is 1/10 (in bridges per minute), B's speed is 1/5, C's speed is 1/2, and the bicycle's speed is 1.
The fastest way to get everyone across is for B and C to start out on foot and A to start out with the bicycle. At a point y, A will get off the bicycle and walk the rest of the way. Eventually C will get to the bicycle abandoned by A, then ride back to a point x, leaving the bicycle there, then turning around and walk until he reaches the end. Person B will walk until he reaches the bicycle left by C and then ride the rest of the way.
Below are the times that each will take to cross, in terms of x and y:
A: 1*y + 10*(1-y)
B: 5*x + 1*(1-x)
C: 2*y + (y-x) + 2*(1-x)
Next equate these equations: 10 - 9y = -3x + 3y + 2 = 4x + 1.
To solve set up two linear equations:
10 - 9y = -3x + 3y + 2 -> 3x - 12y = -8
10 - 9y = 4x + 1 -> 4x + 9y = 9
Then solve for x and y:
x = 12/25, y=59/75.
Given these points it will take each person 73/25 = 2.92 minutes to cross. Since they all start and end at the same time, the total duration to cross the bridge is also 2.92 minutes.
Response:
Let the bridge have length L.  
The three men’s walking speeds are therefore

• A : L / 10   (crosses in 10 min)  
• B : L / 5    (crosses in 5  min)  
• C : L / 2    (crosses in 2  min)

With the bicycle any one man can cross in 1 minute, i.e. at speed L / 1.

Key observations

1.  At most one man can use the bicycle, because once it reaches the far side it will not be brought back (that would only add time).  
2.  All three may be on the bridge at the same time; their motions are independent because each travels at his own constant rate.

Because the total time required is the moment when the last man steps off the bridge, we must minimize the largest individual crossing time.

Choosing who rides the bicycle

• If A rides the bicycle his time = 1 min, while B and C walk in 5 and 2 minutes.  
  The latest finishing time is max{1, 5, 2} = 5 minutes.

• If B rides the bicycle his time = 1 min, while A and C walk in 10 and 2 minutes.  
  Latest finishing time = max{10, 1, 2} = 10 minutes.

• If C rides the bicycle his time = 1 min, while A and B walk in 10 and 5 minutes.  
  Latest finishing time = max{10, 5, 1} = 10 minutes.

Thus the only advantageous assignment is to let the slowest walker, A, use the bicycle.

Achievability in 5 minutes

At time 0  
– A starts across on the bicycle (1 minute).  
– B and C start walking (5 minutes and 2 minutes respectively).

Arrivals  
t = 1 min : A is across.  
t = 2 min : C is across.  
t = 5 min : B is across.

Hence by t = 5 minutes all three men are on the far side of the bridge.

Optimality

No schedule can finish in less than 5 minutes, because B requires at least 5 minutes to cross unless he is the bicyclist, and assigning the bicycle to B leaves A needing 10 minutes. Therefore 5 minutes is the minimum possible.

Final answer: 5 minutes

Question:
The card game Snapoker is a very complex game for four players, requiring the use of two decks of cards with all odd spades, even hearts, prime diamonds (including aces) and non-prime clubs (including aces) removed.  Note that jacks are 11, queens are 12, kings are 13.  Two jokers are added to the deck and are each worth 15.  The cards are dealt among the four players.  A hand starts when the dealer shouts "Let's Snapoker!"  Following a frenetic minute of randomly throwing all cards onto the table, and at the dealer's call of "Heeeeeeere, piggy, piggy, piggy!" players are required to grab as many cards as they can.  Once all cards have been grabbed, the total value of the cards in each player's hand is added up.  Points (4, 3, 2 and 1) are awarded to players on each hand, with the highest card total receiving maximum points.  In the event of a tie, the player who can drink a glass of milk through their nose the quickest will receive the greater points.  A running score is kept throughout the game.  The game is over when someone reaches a total of 518 points or when a fight breaks out, which is a common occurrence.
In a game of Snapoker I was playing the other day, my good friend Kasy managed to grab 13 cards that formed an alternating-colours straight (ie. the odd cards were all red, the evens were all black).  How many different ways can a 13-card alternating-colour straight be formed from a Snapoker deck?  Note that jokers can not be used in forming a straight.
Hint: Simply find the number of cards of each type of card in the alternating-colors straight
Human Solution:
There are 32,768 possible ways a 13-card alternating-colour straight can be formed in a Snapoker deck.
To form a 13-card alternating-colour straight in Snapoker the following cards can be used:
2 x red aces
4 x black twos
2 x red threes
2 x black fours
2 x red fives
2 x black sixes
2 x red sevens
2 x black eights
4 x red nines
2 x black tens
2 x red jacks
2 x black queens
2 x red kings
Therefore, there are 2x4x2x2x2x2x2x2x4x2x2x2x2 = 32,768 possible 13-card alternating-colour straights that can be formed.
Response:
First isolate the cards that actually exist in a Snapoker deck.

1.  Two ordinary decks are combined, so every card that remains occurs in duplicate.

2.  Cards removed   
   • odd-numbered spades (1,3,5,7,9,11,13)  
   • even-numbered hearts (2,4,6,8,10,12)  
   • diamonds whose rank is prime or ace (A,2,3,5,7,11,13)  
   • clubs whose rank is non-prime or ace (A,4,6,8,9,10,12)

Hence the cards that are still present are

   Hearts (red) : 1,3,5,7,9,11,13  
   Diamonds (red): 4,6,8,9,10,12  
   Spades (black): 2,4,6,8,10,12  
   Clubs  (black): 2,3,5,7,11,13  

and each of these cards appears twice (because there are two decks).

--------------------------------------------------------------------
Determine the permissible card choices for the required straight

An “alternating-colours straight’’ must contain the thirteen consecutive
ranks A,2,3, … ,K with

   • every odd rank red,
   • every even rank black.

Treat each rank separately and list how many physical cards can be chosen
for it.

Odd ranks  (must be red)

 rank 1 : 2 × (♥A)                                   → 2 ways  
 rank 3 : 2 × (♥3)                                   → 2 ways  
 rank 5 : 2 × (♥5)                                   → 2 ways  
 rank 7 : 2 × (♥7)                                   → 2 ways  
 rank 9 : 2 × (♥9)  +  2 × (♦9)                      → 4 ways  
 rank 11: 2 × (♥J)                                   → 2 ways  
 rank 13: 2 × (♥K)                                   → 2 ways  

Product for the seven odd ranks
        2·2·2·2·4·2·2 = 2^8 = 256 ways.

Even ranks (must be black)

 rank 2 : 2 × (♠2)  +  2 × (♣2)                      → 4 ways  
 rank 4 : 2 × (♠4)                                   → 2 ways  
 rank 6 : 2 × (♠6)                                   → 2 ways  
 rank 8 : 2 × (♠8)                                   → 2 ways  
 rank 10: 2 × (♠10)                                  → 2 ways  
 rank 12: 2 × (♠12)                                  → 2 ways  

Product for the six even ranks
        4·2·2·2·2·2 = 2^7 = 128 ways.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
Combine the choices

Because the choice for each rank is independent of the others,
the total number of different 13-card alternating-colour straights is

        256 × 128 = 2^15 = 32 768.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
Final answer: 32,768

Question: Arrange the digits 0, 1, 2, 2, 3, 4, 4, 5, 6, and 9, to form a single fraction that equals 1/2.  (Here is one example that, alas, turns out not to be true:  32145/24690=1/2)
Hint: Try to group some numbers together that yield a ratio of 1/2
Human Solution: Try to group some numbers together that yield a ratio of 1/2 One solution:  12345/24690=1/2
Response:
Let  

N = n₁ n₂ n₃ n₄ n₅ (numerator) , D = d₁ d₂ d₃ d₄ d₅ (denominator)  

denote the two five-digit numbers that must satisfy
